title: Democrats Dominate Fundraising in Georgia Senate Runoffs
summary: Ossoff, Warnock raised a combined $210 million in two months as they seek to unseat GOP Sens. Loeffler, Perdue in Jan. 5 election.. Democrats are pouring money into the Georgia special election that will determine which party controls the Senate, with candidates Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock together collecting more than $210 million in two months, new fundraising filings show.

title: Ted Cruz and Hong Kong's Democrats
summary: The Senator blocks a bill opening America's door to victims of China.. Rafael Cruz, the father of Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, came to the U.S. from Cuba in 1957 on a four-year student visa. He had sided with Fidel Castro against the Batista dictatorship, for which he was jailed and beaten. But he later soured on Castro and was granted political asylum in the U.S.

title: A Lone Star Speech Victory
summary: The University of Texas at Austin will dissolve its bias-response team.. Political speech is under attack these days from Beijing to Berkeley, so we'll take victories where we can get them. One arrived Tuesday when the University of Texas at Austin agreed to disband its PC police and end policies that suppress speech on campus.

title: Peggy Noonan Forgot to Thank Trump for Vaccines
summary: She also didn't mention Operation Warp Speed once.. In "The Monday When America Came Back" (Declarations, Dec. 19), Peggy Noonan elegantly outlines the miracle of the vaccine. But as I continued reading, I waited for her to explain how this miracle was made possible. Finally, at the end, when she mentioned a man "half crazy, almost a genius," I knew the moment was near: She would finally mention the leader behind it all, the reason for our Christmas miracle. But she never did. And what an incredible disappointment. Operation Warp Speed wasn't mentioned once. Neither was the president's name.

title: What 'Diversity and Inclusion' Can Conceal
summary: The Democratic Party seems more like a coalition of disparate groups.. Reading Daniel Henninger's "Joe Biden's Cabinet of Diversity" (Wonder Land, Dec. 17), I was reminded of parliamentary governments around the world. Often no party gets a majority of seats and a coalition must be built to get a prime minister. In building the coalition, cabinet posts are often used as barter.

title: Bob Dylan, Capitalist? The Times They Are a-Changin'
summary: I remember so well some of those early songs with an antiestablishment theme of protest.. As a longtime fan, I find it ironic that Bob Dylan sold his entire publishing catalog, likely worth hundreds of millions of dollars ("Dylan Sells Catalog to Universal," Business & Finance, Dec. 8). I remember so well some of those early songs with an antiestablishment theme of protest. Mr. Dylan now deservedly reaps the benefits of his incredible creativity from the capitalist system that he wasn't so sure about back in 1963. What a country!

title: The Case Against Leaving Our Afghan Allies in the Lurch
summary: Consider the safety and well-being of more than 30 million Afghans.. In "Now Is as Good a Time as Any for the U.S. to Quit Afghanistan" (op-ed, Dec. 11), Gil Barndollar and Sam Long make their case for American withdrawal by focusing on the safety of U.S. forces. But what about the safety and well-being of more than 30 million Afghans?

title: President Trump Exits the White House as He Entered
summary: It's all about him.. Your editorial "Trump's Bad Exit" (Dec. 21) contains the subheading "As his days in office dwindle, he's making everything about him." When was this ever not the case?

title: Flying Over the Holidays? Here Are the Covid-19 Complications
summary: Measures to prevent transmission have changed since the start of the pandemic. Air travel has become a fraught, complicated prospect this holiday season.

title: Three Generations on the Police Beat
summary: Recently retired after 38 years in the NYPD, John McAuliffe says the force is 'demoralized.' He's no fan of Mayor de Blasio, and Black Lives Matter makes him see red.. Staten Island, N.Y.

title: A Look Back at the Pandemic Year
summary: All our lives changed in 2020, and it's only beginning to become clear how and how much.. Twenty twenty defies summation. All of us tried; no words ever seemed to capture the whole. But three things are true:

title: Trump Gives Some Federal Workers Christmas Eve Off-Though Congress Is on the Job
summary: Previous presidents have customarily given federal workers a half-day off on Dec. 24 when Christmas has fallen on a Friday. WASHINGTON-For the third year in a row, President Trump has given employees of the executive branch of the federal government a full day off on Christmas Eve, though Congress remained on the job Thursday morning.

title: Christmases Past and Future
summary: The suspension of a beloved tradition reminds us of the courage that secured the blessings of liberty.. Another event cancellation driven by state governors acting like "petty tyrants" reminds us of the people who allowed us to live free of major tyrants.

title: House Efforts to Alter Virus Package Fail, Leaving Aid in Limbo
summary: Dueling moves to boost direct payments, cut foreign aid were blocked, as President Trump remained silent on his plans. WASHINGTON-Republicans blocked Democrats' effort to pass legislation approving $2,000 stimulus checks for Americans by unanimous consent in the U.S. House, and countered with an attempt to cut foreign aid that was thwarted by Democrats in turn.

title: Treasury Yields Slip in Holiday-Shortened Session
summary: Investors focus on trade deal reached between the U.K. and EU. U.S. government-bond yields fell Thursday as Wall Street winds downs in a shortened trading session.

title: Why Prime Rib Makes the Best Christmas Dinner
summary: The classic steakhouse dinner is a Christmas tradition for many, but with smaller gatherings at home this year, a 10-pound rack of beef may not be the best option. Below, some suggestions on how to maintain the spirit of a standing rib roast dinner.. A year ago, I wouldn't have described myself as a nostalgic person or someone who craves annual holiday celebrations. But since the beginning of December, I've been feeling like something is missing. Yes, like many people I'm celebrating the holidays without the usual cast of loved ones. Yet, also absent are some of the traditions that make this time of year special.One of those rituals that's tugging at both my heart and my appetite this time of year is prime rib.

title: What to Stream in January 2021: Three TV Series With Binge-Worthy Décor
summary: The set decoration in this Netflix Original (and two other streamable shows) will have design-lovers clicking 'Next Episode' until the season's final curtain. WITH DESIGN museums and historic homes off-limits, these streaming series, premiering or returning in the next month, are a satisfying substitute for décor junkies.

title: Prosperity After Brexit
summary: The last-minute trade deal opens new doors for the U.K., EU and U.S.. Brexit came down to the wire but it arrived Thursday, with a new trade deal between the United Kingdom and European Union. Arguments about whether this is a good or bad deal for either side matter less than the fact that British voters have finally received what they voted for in 2016.

title: U.K., EU Reach Historic Trade Deal, Capping Brexit Saga
summary: Accord sets out terms of a much more distant relationship, averts worst fears of economic disruption. The U.K. and the European Union secured an agreement over their future relations, setting the seal on the 2016 British referendum decision to leave the bloc and bringing to a close years of economic uncertainty and fraught politics in the U.K.

title: Finding the Sacred in the Delights of Christmas
summary: More than a season of good cheer, the holiday asks believers to think about reality itself in new ways.. Christmas came early to my town this year. Even before the children made their socially distanced way from house to house for trick-or-treating, the storefronts and houses of Berwyn, Pa., were decorated in long coils of Christmas lights. On our local online discussion board, one woman said that she wished everyone could have just waited until after Thanksgiving and the beginning of Advent. Seasonal decorations, after all, are properly reserved for the season.

title: Beijing Sends Alibaba an Unwelcome Christmas Present
summary: Government's antitrust broadside against Chinese tech giant marks an escalation in hostilities. The billionaire founder of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba is unlikely to have a merry Christmas this year.

title: Temporary SEC Leadership Is Set After Chairman's Recent Departure
summary: Elad Roisman is expected to succeed Jay Clayton during final weeks of President Trump's term. WASHINGTON-Elad Roisman is expected to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission after Chairman Jay Clayton's recent departure, a fellow commissioner at the agency said Thursday.

title: Stocks End Modestly Higher in Shortened Session
summary: Weak economic data has bolstered hopes that an agreement will be reached on coronavirus-aid package. U.S. stocks rose Thursday in light holiday trading as investors tracked the latest developments on a new coronavirus aid package and the historic trade deal reached between the U.K. and European Union.

title: Biden to Review U.S. Nuclear-Weapons Programs, With Eye Toward Cuts
summary: President-elect promised to reduce 'excessive' spending on nuclear arsenal and shrink its role in strategy, but critics say updates are overdue. summary: Here are five things to know about how the agreement could impact the finance industry in the U.K. and EU. The U.K. government and the European Union have agreed a trade deal to replace current arrangements which end on New Year's Eve when the Brexit process is completed.

summary: The Brexit transition period is set to end Dec. 31. Companies need to be aware of likely changes to the U.K.'s sanctions regime as the end of the Brexit transition period approaches, sanctions compliance attorneys said.

title: Carbon Prices Jump Despite Record Drop in Emissions
summary: European Union's decision to curb greenhouse gases is driving the latest rally, putting carbon credits on par with gold. Credits tied to carbon emissions are having a banner year despite a record drop in output from the power plants and steel mills that need them to operate.

title: 'Covid': The New Coinage That Defined 2020
summary: An acronym that didn't exist in 2019 has been proclaimed Word of the Year for the long shadow it has cast over our language. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: Number Puzzles
The Most Interesting Real-Estate Stories of 2020
summary: Our reporters examined how the pandemic has reshaped markets, the way we design and build homes and how industry professionals do business. At the start of 2020, Mansion's reporting stretched from the Koch brothers' vast (and very expensive) real-estate portfolio to how retirees could apply for mortgages on a fixed income. There was the story about Madrid's luxury market finally putting the 2008 financial crisis in the rearview mirror. And the other that looked at why wealthy millennials were eschewing the suburbs for move-in ready homes close to cities.

title: Britain, EU Prepare Borders for Life After Brexit
summary: Both sides are spending huge sums on parking lots, portable toilets along highways and thousands of new customs officials. A giant parking lot on a disused airfield in southern England. Portable toilets on highways leading to English Channel ports. Thousands of customs officials. And an expensive advertising campaign.

title: China's Antitrust Probe Zeroes In on Vendor Claims of Alibaba Pressure
summary: Chinese tech companies face both increasing political pressure at home and intensified scrutiny in the U.S..

title: 'Icebound' Review: Into the Void
summary: Seeking an ocean passage to China, William Barents set the template for polar adventure and endurance.. The cold, hoary legacy of polar exploration depends on outsize characters-and good books. Some chronicle legendary survivors. Ernest Shackleton found fame in 1917 by bringing his crew safely back from Antarctica, yielding one of the best adventure stories ever written: Alfred Lansing's "Endurance." Other explorers made their way into print by dying. John Franklin, who was lost in 1847 trying to find the Northwest Passage, inspired such titles as "The Man Who Ate His Boots." The Norwegian Roald Amundsen both survived and disappeared. He forced the Northwest Passage in 1905 and then led the first expedition to the South Pole, recounting his adventures in several bestsellers. Amundsen later perished in an Arctic rescue mission. Conquest and tragedy fused to form the ideal polar hero.

title: Schools Rethink Covid Rules. 'We're Over-Quarantining Kids Like Crazy.'
summary: Resume Subscription. Superintendent Jonathan Cooper this summer helped write a fall reopening plan for his southwestern Ohio school district with a rule based on the state's policy: Any student potentially exposed to Covid-19 in Mason City Schools had to quarantine for two weeks, no exceptions.

title: Appreciation: John le Carré, 1931-2020
summary: Frustrated by James Bond-style myths, John le Carré fashioned a literature of betrayal and the cost of secrets.. The late John le Carré, born David John Moore Cornwell in 1931, liked to quote fellow English novelist Graham Greene to the effect that "childhood is the writer's bank balance." Thanks to an anxious upbringing, young David acquired enough authorial capital for the future le Carré to produce 26 books: tales of espionage and more that injected emotional complexity into "the secret world" and transformed spy fiction forever.

title: 'Follies' Review: Castle Frivolous
summary: Tiny towers, fake ruins and Greek temples for the garden: the joys of a very English architectural obsession.. The subject of this discursive book is the architectural folly, which the British author Rory Fraser describes as "an elaborate building set in a beautiful landscape that serves no purpose other than to improve the view: architecture for the sake of architecture." Follies originated as a feature of English and French 18th-century landscape gardening, and were typically Greek temples, turreted towers and picturesque ruins. The Great Pagoda in Kew Gardens is an example; so is the Temple of Love built for Marie-Antoinette in the garden of Versailles.

title: Brexit Deal Brings Clarity but Not Closure
summary: While the historic agreement signed by the U.K. and European Union on Christmas Eve removes the risk of very bad economic outcomes, it leaves much up in the air. For the Brexit process, the deal announced by the U.K. and the European Union on Christmas Eve marks a long-awaited end to the beginning.

title: Rosen Takes Reins of a Justice Department Under Pressure
summary: Acting attorney general is expected to face continuing demands from President Trump regarding election. Jeffrey Rosen, now acting attorney general, inherits the reins of a Justice Department under pressure from President Trump to take action in the waning days of his administration on numerous legal controversies of intense interest to him.

title: 'The Unquiet Englishman' Review: Many Shades of Greene
summary: Finding the balance between the twin myths of Graham Greene's inner demons and his questing spirit.. In stark chronological terms, Graham Greene (1904-1991) was a member of that spangled generation of British writers born in the golden decade between 1900 and 1910, a logjam of talent that included such mighty timbers as George Orwell and Evelyn Waugh (both born in 1903), Christopher Isherwood (1904), Anthony Powell and Henry Green (both 1905) and W.H. Auden (1907). Generational solidarity went only so far among this gang of highly individual Edwardian contenders, and so the views of Greene held by his professional peers are always worth attending to.

title: Second Stimulus Checks: Could Trump Veto the Relief Bill?
summary: Congress voted to authorize another round of direct payments to households-but President Trump has called for more. Congress voted Monday to authorize a second round of stimulus payments to households as part of its roughly $900 billion coronavirus relief legislation. President Trump had been expected to sign the legislation, but he criticized the deal Tuesday night and called on lawmakers to increase direct payments to Americans to $2,000 from $600. Here is what we know:

title: Post-Pandemic Future May Not Match Investor Fantasies
summary: Market valuations suggest the world will step into a Jetsons-like future almost as soon as vaccinations are complete. When the world eventually opens back up, consumers will step out into a buzzing utopia of technological riches. At least, that is what the stock market would have you believe.

title: Logistics Report: Delivering More Doses; Crackdown on Alibaba; Peloton's Faster Gear
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Fiction: Memento Mori
summary: Contemporary novelists readily take on the end of the world. The end of a life is a tougher subject.. There is a hole in contemporary fiction that has been noticeable for some time but was especially conspicuous in this year. Novelists are obsessed with the apocalypse and have envisioned countless scenarios for the downfall of civilization. Equally, they are transfixed by grief and repeatedly are drawn to produce meditations on loss and recovery. But they do not like to write about the subtext of these preoccupations, the thing that they are hinting toward or circling around, cautiously evoking yet usually leaving off the page. They do not like to write about death.

title: Children's Books: Too Much Too Soon
summary: A look at well-intentioned but off-target books for little ones-and a few that hit the mark.. Most of the year, this column is devoted to the best new books for young readers. Not so this week. As a last gasp of our annus horribilis, let's talk about what makes for a bad book; specifically, what makes for a lousy board book for babies and toddlers. As for why publishers produced so many, I suppose the usual answer applies: It's 2020. What do you expect?

title: From Jon Hamm to Candice Bergen, What 18 Notables Watched and Read During the Pandemic
summary: Covid has turned even cultural luminaries into homebodies. We asked 18 musicians, actors, artists, designers and authors to share their favorite quarantine discoveries.. IT FEELS almost callous to call anything a silver lining in 2020, but during this tumultuous year, many people eagerly took shelter in culture, high and low. Film, TV, books and music gave us relief and a center of gravity. In the interest of tallying up the silver linings and seeking recommendations to help us weather the next few months, we asked 18 well-known cultural figures to share their favorite quarantine discoveries and comfort fare. Many were drawn to the familiar. Actor Jon Hamm, for example, spent part of his downtime consuming comedies from the 1970s and 1980s that he remembered from his youth. "I found myself, like a lot of people, going back to what feels comfortable and knowable, because so much of our existence in the last eight months has been uncomfortable and unknowable," he said.

title: Cocktail Books: Here's to Simple Pleasures
summary: Homebound holidays make knowing how to mix a drink particularly rewarding. And it doesn't have to be complex.. Last December a group of cocktail virtuosi in Washington, D.C., put on their annual holiday cocktail seminar. The invitation promised that "DC's finest bartenders" would present original holiday cocktails. "They'll tell the story of what inspired the drink, and show you how to make the drink at home," the promoters said. "And best of all, they'll serve it to you!"

title: Five Best: On Civil Wars Within Families
summary: Selected by Rachel Holmes, author of 'Sylvia Pankhurst: Natural Born Rebel.'. By Amanda Foreman (2010)

title: My Unlikely Path from a Valley in Nepal to the Halls of Harvard
summary: Growing up amid political conflict and economic uncertainty made me determined to give back to my community. I am not your average Harvard student. My family's annual income is less than $3,000, neither of my parents speak English or have graduated from college and I had no clue what the SAT was when I first decided to apply to colleges in the U.S.

title: Harvard Professor Ezra Vogel Dug Deeply Into East Asian Cultures
summary: Scholar, who has died at age 90, aimed to prod America with 1979 book 'Japan as Number One'. Ezra F. Vogel chose a bold title for his 1979 book on Japan's growing economic power: "Japan as Number One: Lessons for America."

title: Covid Threw People's Finances Into Disarray
summary: Resume Subscription. 2020 has been heartbreaking, unpredictable and poignant. summary: Resume Subscription. Fear jolted Jamie Dimon awake in the dark morning hours of March 5.

title: How HIV Research Laid the Foundation for Covid Vaccines
summary: Scientific techniques developed in the ongoing fight against AIDS helped scientists combat the new coronavirus. People are receiving Covid-19 vaccines less than a year after public health authorities discovered SARS-CoV-2, the deadly new coronavirus. How did it happen so quickly? In part, the world can thank decades of frustrating and often fruitless research to find a vaccine for Human Immunodeficiency Virus or HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Many of the new technologies and approaches employed to create potent Covid-19 vaccines and therapies trace their origins to the desperate search, starting in the early 1980s, to slow the spread of HIV.

title: Gas Is Cleaner Than Oil, But It Still Has a Transition Problem
summary: Natural gas will play a key role in the shift to renewable energy, but that is no guarantee it will provide good returns. As a relatively clean fossil fuel, natural gas will play a useful role for years to come. It is less certain that it will be a profitable one.

title: U.K., EU Poised to Agree on Post-Brexit Trade Deal
summary: Agreement should be reached in the coming hours, say people close to the talks. BRUSSELS-A post-Brexit trade accord between the U.K. and the European Union was being held up by last-minute negotiations over fisheries, officials said, but people close to the talks said a deal should be sealed in the coming hours.

title: Durant, Irving and a Quirky NBA Contender in Brooklyn
summary: After a long wait, two superstars pair in a borough where the public still can't get into the arena. Weird is easily the most overused word in sports in 2020-to the point the term has been rendered all but meaningless. I'm as guilty as anyone, and I should knock it off. Everything is weird about sports now: near-empty stadia; Zoom press conferences; face-masked coaches; piped-in crowd noise; the freaking Rose Bowl being played in Texas next week. Texas!

title: Three Astros Were Suspended For Cheating. Two Are Already Back.
summary: A.J. Hinch and Alex Cora return to baseball this season but Jeff Luhnow appears to have a challenging road ahead to work in the industry again. Boston Red Sox manager Alex Cora fielded questions for more than 30 minutes at last week's winter meetings, an annual tradition of the baseball offseason that moved from a hotel ballroom to Zoom this year. He was asked about slugger J.D. Martinez's disappointing 2020 season, the team's hole at second base and pitcher Eduardo Rodríguez's health-standard questions for somebody in Cora's position.

title: Through AIDS, Ebola and Covid, Dr. Fauci Is Still Treating Patients
summary: The nation's top infectious-disease official received the vaccine in part because he still does rounds in the hospital several days a week.. Nina Pham was tired, weak and heavily medicated. The first person to contract the Ebola virus on American soil, she had been rushed by ambulance to the National Institutes of Health, where she was being treated in the most secure room of perhaps the nation's most prestigious medical facility. Ms. Pham didn't know who her doctor was. She wouldn't have recognized him anyway in his protective armor.

summary: Pandemic obliges separated families to shift traditional rituals online, to the chagrin of many. title: Covid-19 Test Makers Aim to Broaden Testing Well Into Spring
summary: U.S. will likely be able to perform 70 million tests a week in January and 200 million a week in April, according to one analysis. title: From Nike to Balenciaga, the Seven Strangest Sneakers of 2020
summary: During a tumultuous year, sneaker companies continued to deliver an incredible number of sneaker designs, some with truly perplexing features--evoking cloven hoofs, teeter-totters and even melting ice-cream cones. title: Businesses Feared a Flood of Covid-19 Lawsuits. It Hasn't Happened.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
